articles.headline: One Dip Into a 401(k) Often Leads to Another
articles.snippet: Borrowing from retirement savings can make sense, but many people become repeat customers, taking multiple loans.
articles.abstract: Borrowing from retirement savings can make sense, but many people become repeat customers, taking multiple loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some people can’t seem to stop at just one.

articles.headline: Chevrolet’s Cheap Minicar, the Spark, Is a Surprisingly Strong Seller
articles.snippet: The four-door Spark, made in South Korea and sold in the United States since last year, starts at $12,170 and gets about 35 miles to the gallon.
articles.abstract: The four-door Spark, made in South Korea and sold in the United States since last year, starts at $12,170 and gets about 35 miles to the gallon.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tiny Chevrolet Spark from General Motors is about as bare bones as cars come these days, with no floor mats and one of the smallest engines of any car. But to the surprise of even G.M. itself, which has traditionally struggled to sell small cars, the Spark has become an unlikely hit as many American buyers warm to a car that is cheap to buy and to operate.

articles.headline: Plan to Ban Oil Drilling in Amazon Is Dropped
articles.snippet: The offer was withdrawn after only $13 million was collected for a proposed $3.6 billion fund to protect nearly 4,000 square miles of rain forest.
articles.abstract: The offer was withdrawn after only $13 million was collected for a proposed $3.6 billion fund to protect nearly 4,000 square miles of rain forest.
articles.lead_paragraph: Six years ago, President Rafael Correa of Ecuador offered the world what he considered an enticing deal: donate $3.6 billion to a trust fund intended to protect nearly 4,000 square miles of the Amazon jungle and his country would refrain from oil drilling in the rain forest.

articles.headline: Ties With Egypt Army Constrain Washington
articles.snippet: With the myriad, though largely invisible, ways the Egyptian military assists United States interests in the region, Egyptian generals have some leverage in facing Washington and its pressure to end a crackdown.
articles.abstract: With the myriad, though largely invisible, ways the Egyptian military assists United States interests in the region, Egyptian generals have some leverage in facing Washington and its pressure to end a crackdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most nations, including many close allies of the United States, require up to a week’s notice before American warplanes are allowed to cross their territory. Not Egypt, which offers near-automatic approval for military overflights, to resupply the war effort in Afghanistan or to carry out counterterrorism operations in the Middle East, Southwest Asia or the Horn of Africa.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: As Investors Jump Ship, SAC Looks to Cut Back
articles.snippet: SAC’s prospects are grim as the fund, while operating under a criminal indictment, prepares to become leaner with virtually no outside investors.
articles.abstract: SAC’s prospects are grim as the fund, while operating under a criminal indictment, prepares to become leaner with virtually no outside investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wildly successful hedge fund SAC Capital Advisors typically heads into the end of the year in a position of strength, promising market-beating returns for its investors and outsize paydays for its owner, Steven A. Cohen.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Peter Lattman

articles.headline: Brown Cheered in Second Act, at Least So Far
articles.snippet: On his second tour as governor of California, Jerry Brown has succeeded in ways few would have imagined when he took office in 2010.
articles.abstract: On his second tour as governor of California, Jerry Brown has succeeded in ways few would have imagined when he took office in 2010.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — When Jerry Brown became governor of California again, three years ago, this state was on a steep decline, crushed by budget deficits, deep spending cuts, governmental paralysis, high unemployment and a collapsing housing market. California, a place that once symbolized promise and opportunity, seemed caught in an intractable reversal of fortune.

articles.headline: Layoffs Taboo, Japan Workers Are Sent to the Boredom Room
articles.snippet: Facing a sluggish economy and increasing competition, Japan’s prime minister and major companies want to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers.
articles.abstract: Facing a sluggish economy and increasing competition, Japan’s prime minister and major companies want to reduce longstanding restrictions on dismissing full-time workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAGAJO, Japan — Shusaku Tani is employed at the Sony plant here, but he doesn’t really work.

articles.headline: Hanging Out at the E-Mall
articles.snippet: Web entrepreneurs are moving closer to duplicating the real-world feel of a mall, where shoppers can pop in and out of multiple stores, and browse with the advice of friends.
articles.abstract: Web entrepreneurs are moving closer to duplicating the real-world feel of a mall, where shoppers can pop in and out of multiple stores, and browse with the advice of friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shopping online is easier than shopping in a mall — as long as you know exactly what you want to buy. The problem comes when you don’t know what you want.

articles.headline: Victims’ Dilemma: 911 Calls Can Bring Eviction
articles.snippet: Aiming to save neighborhoods from blight and to ease burdens on the police, municipalities have adopted ordinances requiring landlords to weed out disruptive tenants.
articles.abstract: Aiming to save neighborhoods from blight and to ease burdens on the police, municipalities have adopted ordinances requiring landlords to weed out disruptive tenants.
articles.lead_paragraph: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — The police had warned Lakisha Briggs: one more altercation at her rented row house here, one more call to 911, and they would force her landlord to evict her.

articles.headline: How American Hopes for a Deal in Egypt Were Undercut
articles.snippet: Egypt’s military crackdown has left President Obama in a no-win position: risk a partnership that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace, or stand by while allies try to hold on to power by mowing down opponents.
articles.abstract: Egypt’s military crackdown has left President Obama in a no-win position: risk a partnership that has been the bedrock of Middle East peace, or stand by while allies try to hold on to power by mowing down opponents.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — For a moment, at least, American and European diplomats trying to defuse the volatile standoff in Egypt thought they had a breakthrough.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Peter Baker and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Trash Into Gas, Efficiently? An Army Test May Tell
articles.snippet: The United States Army will be the first to test a system by Sierra Energy to turn waste — whether banana peels, used syringes, old iPods, even raw sewage — into fuel.
articles.abstract: The United States Army will be the first to test a system by Sierra Energy to turn waste — whether banana peels, used syringes, old iPods, even raw sewage — into fuel.
articles.lead_paragraph: THERE is an indisputable elegance to the idea of transforming garbage into fuel, of turning icky, smelly detritus into something valuable.

articles.headline: The Problem With Wiggle Room in Securities
articles.snippet: The case against two former traders at JPMorgan Chase has larger lessons for investors and regulators.
articles.abstract: The case against two former traders at JPMorgan Chase has larger lessons for investors and regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: TO veterans of Wall Street, the details that emerged in last week’s criminal complaints against two former JPMorgan Chase traders didn’t exactly shock. Over the years, countless traders have misrepresented the values of the securities they hold, hoping that a market move will reverse a looming loss.

articles.headline: Expecting the Unexpected From Jeff Bezos
articles.snippet: At Amazon.com, he has upended industries. Now he promises change at The Washington Post. If his history is a guide, he will have all the laughs.
articles.abstract: At Amazon.com, he has upended industries. Now he promises change at The Washington Post. If his history is a guide, he will have all the laughs.
articles.lead_paragraph: EARLY employees of Amazon still remember the day the company took away their aspirin.
articles.byline: By David Streitfeld and Christine Haughney

articles.headline: Hiring in China by JPMorgan Under Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Authorities have opened a bribery investigation into whether JPMorgan Chase hired the children of powerful Chinese officials to help the bank win lucrative business in the booming nation.
articles.abstract: Authorities have opened a bribery investigation into whether JPMorgan Chase hired the children of powerful Chinese officials to help the bank win lucrative business in the booming nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have opened a bribery investigation into whether JPMorgan Chase hired the children of powerful Chinese officials to help the bank win lucrative business in the booming nation, according to a confidential United States government document.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Ben Protess and David Barboza

articles.headline: Islamists Killed While in Custody, Egypt Confirms
articles.snippet: The deaths were the fourth mass killing of civilians since the military took control on July 3, but the first time those killed were in government custody at the time.
articles.abstract: The deaths were the fourth mass killing of civilians since the military took control on July 3, but the first time those killed were in government custody at the time.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The Egyptian government acknowledged that its security forces had killed 36 Islamists in its custody on Sunday, as the country’s military leaders and Islamists vowed to keep up their fight over Egypt’s future.

articles.headline: Most of U.S. Is Wired, but Millions Aren’t Plugged In
articles.snippet: The Obama administration is concerned that 60 million are shut out of jobs, government services, health care and education, and that the economic effects are looming larger.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration is concerned that 60 million are shut out of jobs, government services, health care and education, and that the economic effects are looming larger.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has poured billions of dollars into expanding the reach of the Internet, and nearly 98 percent of American homes now have access to some form of high-speed broadband. But tens of millions of people are still on the sidelines of the digital revolution.

articles.headline: Public Funds Take Control of Assets, Dodging Wall Street
articles.snippet: The shift is motivated, in no small part, by the high fees and lackluster performance that many hedge funds and private equity firms have delivered to their biggest clients in recent years.
articles.abstract: The shift is motivated, in no small part, by the high fees and lackluster performance that many hedge funds and private equity firms have delivered to their biggest clients in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors responsible for more than $2 trillion recently gathered at a resort in the Canadian Rockies, far from the news media and, more important, far from Wall Street.

articles.headline: Firefighters’ Survivor Benefits Value Some Lives Over Others
articles.snippet: In life, firefighters from disparate states and backgrounds work side by side. But in death, families say, they are sifted into categories based on their official employment status.
articles.abstract: In life, firefighters from disparate states and backgrounds work side by side. But in death, families say, they are sifted into categories based on their official employment status.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — As a wilderness firefighter, Caleb Renno hiked over mountains until his heels bled, living out of tents and eating packaged food for weeks at a time in rugged corners of the burning West. He did not love the work, but like many young adults in southern Oregon, he knew he could always find steady pay fighting fires.

articles.headline: A Television Unit Flourishes in an Often Overlooked Corner of Sony
articles.snippet: Sony Pictures Television has gone largely underacknowledged, but that is changing, partly because of prodding from one of its largest shareholders.
articles.abstract: Sony Pictures Television has gone largely underacknowledged, but that is changing, partly because of prodding from one of its largest shareholders.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULVER CITY, Calif. — Next month, the broadcast networks will introduce more than 20 new series, and four of the most ambitious will be supplied by Sony.

articles.headline: Baidu Deal May Reduce App Piracy in China
articles.snippet: The move should also help Baidu regain ground against two other Chinese Internet giants, Alibaba and Tencent, which were quicker to add mobile capabilities.
articles.abstract: The move should also help Baidu regain ground against two other Chinese Internet giants, Alibaba and Tencent, which were quicker to add mobile capabilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — The biggest Internet takeover to date in China has already sharpened a rivalry among the country’s digital powerhouses, but the deal could also bring more order to China’s messy world of mobile apps.

articles.headline: An Afghan Poet Shapes Metal and Hard Words
articles.snippet: Many Afghans who have grown cynical after years of war have found a voice in a sharp-tongued poet who fixes trucks by day and writes by night.
articles.abstract: Many Afghans who have grown cynical after years of war have found a voice in a sharp-tongued poet who fixes trucks by day and writes by night.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHOST, Afghanistan — The poet guided a strip of sheet metal into the ancient steel clippers, cutting shimmering triangles that fell with a dull clang on the shop floor.

articles.headline: Al Jazeera America Promises a More Sober Look at the News
articles.snippet: When the cable news channel begins broadcasting on Tuesday, “there will be less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings,” its chief says.
articles.abstract: When the cable news channel begins broadcasting on Tuesday, “there will be less opinion, less yelling and fewer celebrity sightings,” its chief says.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fourteen hours of straight news every day. Hard-hitting documentaries. Correspondents in oft-overlooked corners of the country. And fewer commercials than any other news channel.

articles.headline: U.S. Workers Are Grounded by Deep Cuts
articles.snippet: Tangible examples of the resulting spending cuts abound five months after lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on how to reduce the nation’s debt.
articles.abstract: Tangible examples of the resulting spending cuts abound five months after lawmakers failed to reach an agreement on how to reduce the nation’s debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Geological visits to monitor volcanoes in Alaska have been scaled back. The defense secretary is traveling to Afghanistan two times a year instead of the usual four. For the first time in nearly three decades, NASA pulled out of the National Space Symposium, in Colorado Springs, even though representatives from France, Germany and China all made the trip.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Ron Nixon

articles.headline: Egypt in Tumult as Court Orders Mubarak Freed
articles.snippet: The order for former President Hosni Mubarak’s release provided another sign of the return of his authoritarian style of government and came as state forces arrested the Muslim Brotherhood’s spiritual leader.
articles.abstract: The order for former President Hosni Mubarak’s release provided another sign of the return of his authoritarian style of government and came as state forces arrested the Muslim Brotherhood’s spiritual leader.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — A court on Monday ordered the release of former President Hosni Mubarak, and for the first time it was conceivable he might go free — a measure of how far the tumult now shaking Egypt has rolled back the sweeping changes and soaring hopes that followed his exit two and a half years ago.
